questions.text: Which of the following cancers is not protective by use of combined oral contraceptives? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast cancer

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) provide protection against several types of cancers through their hormonal effects. This protective effect can be remembered using the mnemonic "CEO" - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian cancers. However, OCPs are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and possibly cervical cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometrial cancer: Incorrect. OCPs are protective against endometrial cancer due to the progesterone component which counteracts unopposed estrogen effects on the endometrium.

 

Option C. Colorectal cancer: Incorrect. OCPs provide protection against colorectal cancer through their hormonal mechanisms.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Incorrect. OCPs significantly reduce the risk of ovarian cancer by suppressing ovulation and reducing the repetitive damage to ovarian epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCPs provide protection against three types of cancers (CEO - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian) but increase the risk of breast cancer and potentially cervical cancer.

questions.text: A dead body is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligature strangulation  

 

The presence of a ligature mark that completely encircles the neck, is horizontal, and located below the level of the thyroid cartilage is indicative of ligature strangulation. This type of mark differentiates it from other forms of neck compression injuries.

 

Additional Clues:

 

  • Dribbling of Saliva: The absence of dribbling of saliva suggests that the cause of death is not hanging. Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throttling: Throttling involves manual strangulation using hands, not a ligature. It would show different injury patterns on the neck.

 

Option C. Gagging: Gagging involves the insertion of a foreign object into the mouth to prevent breathing, which would show different internal and external signs.

 

Option D. Hanging: Hanging would typically show a ligature mark that is oblique and above the level of the thyroid cartilage, along with signs such as dribbling of saliva.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following pharyngeal arches do not play a role in the development of the definitive adult tongue? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 2nd pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation: 

 

The 2nd pharyngeal arch does not contribute to the formation of the definitive adult tongue. During tongue development, the 2nd arch mesoderm gets buried below the surface as the 3rd arch mesoderm grows over it to fuse with the mesoderm of the 1st arch. The 2nd arch structures are overgrown and do not form any part of the definitive tongue.

 

Contributions of the other pharyngeal arches:

  • Option A. 1st pharyngeal arch: Forms the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via two lingual swellings and tuberculum impar. This "oral part" of the tongue is innervated by the mandibular branch (V3) for general sensation and chorda tympani (VII) for taste.
  • Option C. 3rd pharyngeal arch: Forms the posterior one-third of the tongue (except the most posterior part). This "pharyngeal part" is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX).
  • Option D. 4th pharyngeal arch: Forms the posterior-most part of the tongue near the vallecula, innervated by the superior laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve (X).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the 1st, 3rd, and 4th pharyngeal arches contribute to the definitive adult tongue, the 2nd pharyngeal arch mesoderm becomes buried and makes no contribution to the final tongue structure.

questions.text: A vegetable vendor with no criminal background, after 1 week is found dead with advanced decomposition. What would you do to recognize the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA profiling

 

After one week liquefaction occurs, so the body undergoes significant decomposition. General recognition is not helpful due to the gross distortion of the body. Dental records are also not useful because teeth typically fall out within three to five days post-mortem. Fingerprints can be compromised as the skin begins to degrade, with degloving of the skin occurring within three to five days and complete skin decomposition taking up to one month. However, DNA profiling remains a reliable method even in advanced decomposition, as DNA can be extracted from bones and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. General recognition: This is ineffective after a week of decomposition due to the significant distortion and liquefaction of the body.

 

Option C. Dental records: Teeth fall out within three to five days after death, making dental records unreliable for identification after one week.

 

Option D. Finger prints: The skin undergoes degloving within three to five days and further decomposition, making fingerprinting unreliable. Additionally, without a criminal background, there would be no pre-existing fingerprint records for comparison.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of advanced decomposition, DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a body, as it can still be obtained from bones and other tissues even after significant decomposition.

questions.text: 2 hours after watching a movie, a patient presented with eye ache and difficulty in vision. The first line of management must be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol + Pilocarpine

 

The scenario described is indicative of an acute angle-closure glaucoma attack, which commonly occurs when a person with a shallow anterior chamber enters a dark environment, such as a movie theater. In the dark, the pupil dilates, and the iris moves peripherally, leading to blockage of the trabecular meshwork and subsequently increased intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition requires urgent management to prevent damage to the optic nerve.

 

Mannitol, a hyperosmotic agent, is administered to quickly reduce the vitreous volume by drawing fluid out of the eye, thereby decreasing IOP. This reduction in vitreous volume allows the lens and iris to move backward, alleviating the blockage of the trabecular meshwork. After the IOP is reduced, Pilocarpine, a miotic agent, is given to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle closure, helping to maintain the IOP at a safer level.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mannitol + Moxifloxacin: Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections. It has no role in the management of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Option C. Mannitol + Atropine: Atropine is a mydriatic agent that dilates the pupil, which would worsen the condition by increasing angle closure. Therefore, it is contraindicated in this scenario.

 

Option D. Mannitol + lubricating eye drops: Lubricating eye drops only provide surface moisture and have no effect on intraocular pressure or the underlying mechanism of angle closure, making them ineffective in this emergency situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line management of acute angle-closure glaucoma involves the use of Mannitol to reduce intraocular pressure followed by Pilocarpine to constrict the pupil and prevent further angle obstruction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of unexplained weight loss, hematuria, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging studies reveal a large renal mass. A renal biopsy has the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromophobe carcinoma

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings are consistent with chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Chromophobe RCC is characterized histologically by large polygonal cells with distinct cell borders, perinuclear halos, and a "plant-like" or "resinoid" nuclear appearance.

 

The biopsy image shows these classic features, which differentiate chromophobe RCC from other renal cancer variants.

 

While clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of RCC, the histological findings of clear cytoplasm with perinuclear clearing are more characteristic of chromophobe carcinoma. This variant is less aggressive compared to clear cell RCC and is often diagnosed with specific features on histopathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clear cell carcinoma: This is the most common type of RCC, characterized by cells with clear cytoplasm due to the presence of glycogen and lipid, which are dissolved during processing. The biopsy image does not show these clear cells, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary RCC is characterized by the presence of papillary structures and foamy macrophages. The biopsy image lacks these papillary features, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Bellini duct carcinoma: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this rare and aggressive form of RCC shows infiltrative growth patterns with prominent desmoplastic reaction. The biopsy does not match these characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromophobe RCC is identified by cells with distinct borders, a plant-like or resinoid nucleus, and a perinuclear halo, distinguishing it from other RCC types.

choices.text: Fracture of the Shaft of Humerus
Fracture of the Shaft of Femur

questions.text: Gallow’s traction is primarily used for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Fracture of the Shaft of Femur

 

Gallows traction is primarily used for fractures of the shaft of femur in infants and very young children (typically under 2 years of age). In this traction method, both lower limbs are suspended vertically from overhead with the hips flexed to 90 degrees, regardless of which femur is fractured. This position allows for proper alignment of the femoral fracture while permitting diaper changes and nursing care. The child's body weight provides the counterforce for the traction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Perthes' Disease is treated with various methods to maintain the femoral head within the acetabulum, including abduction braces, casting, or surgical containment, but Gallows traction is not typically used for this condition.

 

Option B: Fractures of the humeral shaft in children are typically treated with hanging arm casts, coaptation splints, or functional bracing. Overhead traction like Gallows traction would not be appropriate for upper extremity fractures.

 

Option D: Pelvic fractures in children are usually treated with bed rest, analgesics, and mobilization as tolerated. More severe fractures might require external fixation or open reduction, but Gallows traction is not used for pelvic fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallows traction is a specific type of skin traction used for femoral shaft fractures in very young children that suspends both legs vertically, utilizing the child's body weight as counter-traction while allowing for easy care and diaper changes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with sudden severe headache. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage)

 

The CT scan shows hyperdensity (bright white areas) within the CSF cisterns, indicating the presence of blood. This presentation is typical of a Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH), which is often caused by a ruptured aneurysm, particularly in the circle of Willis, as confirmed by the accompanying CT angiography. The sudden severe headache experienced by the patient, often described as a "thunderclap headache," is characteristic of SAH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SDH (Subdural Hemorrhage): SDH typically appears as a crescent-shaped collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid membrane. It is not confined to the CSF cisterns and does not present with the sudden onset severe headache seen in SAH.

 

Option C. EDH (Epidural Hemorrhage): EDH is characterized by a biconvex, lens-shaped appearance on imaging. It is usually associated with trauma and does not involve the subarachnoid space or present with CSF cistern hyperdensity.

 

Option D. Pneumocephalus: This condition involves the presence of air within the cranial cavity, often due to trauma or surgical procedures. It shows air density areas on imaging, which appear black, unlike the hyperdense (white) blood seen in SAH. The classic sign associated with pneumocephalus is the Mount Fuji sign, which is not seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SAH presents with sudden, severe headache and is identified on CT by hyperdensity in the CSF cisterns. The most common cause is aneurysmal rupture, best evaluated using CT angiography.

choices.text: Heparan sulfate
Collagen Type IV

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Heparan sulfate

 

Explanation

 

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is an essential component of the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. As the major determinants of the anionic charge of the GBM, heparan sulfate chains have been thought to impart charge selectivity to the glomerular filtration. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibronectin: While fibronectin is involved in cell adhesion and matrix assembly, it does not primarily contribute to the charge-dependent filtration properties of the GBM.

 

Option C. Collagen Type IV: This type of collagen forms a structural scaffolding in the GBM, providing mechanical strength and stability rather than charge-based selectivity.

 

Option D. Entactin: Also known as nidogen, entactin helps link the network of laminin and collagen IV in the GBM but does not directly influence charge-based filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heparan sulfate is the critical component responsible for the charge-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane. Its negative charge effectively repels similarly charged molecules, preventing their passage into the urine, which is essential for the body's ability to retain vital proteins and other negatively charged substances.

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
 

Explanation

 

'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Contraction of right atrium: This is incorrect for the 'C' wave. The contraction of the right atrium produces the 'A' wave in the JVP, not the 'C' wave. The 'A' wave occurs due to atrial contraction pushing blood against a closed tricuspid valve at the end of diastole.

 

Option C. Passive filling of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive filling of the right atrium contributes to the 'V' wave, which occurs when the right atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole and the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Option D. Passive emptying of right atrium: Incorrect for the 'C' wave. Passive emptying of the right atrium is associated with the 'Y' descent, which happens when the tricuspid valve opens in early diastole and blood flows from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

questions.text: Most important enzyme in acute inflammation during respiratory burst is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

The respiratory burst is a crucial process in the immune response where neutrophils rapidly increase their oxygen consumption to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill invading pathogens. The key enzyme that initiates this process is NADPH oxidase (aka Respiratory burst oxidase enzyme). NADPH oxidase catalyzes the conversion of oxygen (O₂) into superoxide anions (O₂⁻), which are then further converted into more reactive species like hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and hypochlorous acid (HOCl-) via other enzymes like myeloperoxidase (MPO). These reactive species are potent antimicrobial agents, essential for destroying bacteria and fungi during acute inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MPO (Myeloperoxidase): While MPO is important in the conversion of hydrogen peroxide into hypochlorous acid (a powerful microbicidal agent), it acts downstream of NADPH oxidase. Thus, it is not the primary enzyme initiating the respiratory burst.

 

Option C. Defensin: Defensins are antimicrobial peptides that kill bacteria particularly against mycobacterium tuberculosis, by disrupting their cell membranes. They do not play a direct role in the respiratory burst or the generation of ROS.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, acting as an antioxidant to protect cells from oxidative damage. It does not contribute to the generation of ROS in the respiratory burst and is involved in mitigating the effects of ROS rather than promoting their formation.

 

Also, Catalase activity is used as a diagnostic tool to differentiate between types of bacteria. For example, the presence of catalase is used to distinguish catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus (staph) from catalase-negative organisms like Streptococcus (strep).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH oxidase is the most important enzyme in the process of respiratory burst during acute inflammation. It initiates the production of reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for the immune system's ability to kill pathogens.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Grey

 

The patient presents with erosions on the cervix, which is indicative of cervicitis. According to the syndromic management guidelines for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), cervicitis is treated with the Grey Kit (Kit 1).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

STI color coded kits:

questions.text: Which type of translocation is seen in diaphyseal tumor with small blue round cells? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T11, 22

 

The question refers to Ewing's sarcoma, a type of malignant tumor that typically affects the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, particularly in children and young adults. The tumor is characterized by small, round, blue cells when viewed under a microscope. A hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma is the t(11;22) translocation, which fuses the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. This translocation results in the production of an abnormal protein that drives the cancer.

 

This translocation, t(11;22), is highly specific for Ewing's sarcoma and is used as a diagnostic marker.

 

Mic 2 (CD99) – Most specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EWSR1, WT1: This combination is incorrect for Ewing's sarcoma. While EWSR1 is involved, WT1 is a gene associated with Wilms' tumor, a kidney cancer, and is not involved in Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Option C. T15,17: This translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), not Ewing's sarcoma. The fusion of the PML and RARA genes occurs in APL.

 

Option D. T2,13: This translocation is associated with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, another type of soft tissue tumor, but not with Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma, a diaphyseal tumor with small, round, blue cells, making it a crucial genetic marker for diagnosis.

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen.  On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.

 

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.

 

IMPERFORATE HYMEN

 

  • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision.

 

 

In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse vaginal septum: Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI

 

Option B. Vaginal atresia: If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant

questions.text: A woman has been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Choose the correct statement? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source

 

The amount of radiation exposure follows Inverse Square law which states that the radiation Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Small blood vessels are radiosensitive.

 

Option C: Cancer cells are rapidly proliferating cells are most radiosensitive.

 

Option D: Bone marrow, gonads, bowel mucosa possess high radiosensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inverse Square Law is critical to understanding radiation dosage and safety in radiotherapy, ensuring that radiation exposure is managed correctly to maximize the therapeutic effect while minimizing harm to healthy tissues. This principle helps in planning and delivering radiation treatments effectively.

questions.text: A young man underwent a surgery on his chest after a trauma an year ago and has developed a lesion as shown. Which of the following is a probable diagnosis in the patient? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keloid

 

The image and clinical history are indicative of a keloid, which is a type of raised scar that grows excessively and extends beyond the original wound boundaries.

 

Keloid:

 

  • Definition: Keloids are overgrowths of scar tissue that develop around a wound, usually after the wound has healed. They are benign and result from an overproduction of collagen.
  • Appearance: Keloids are raised, thick, and can be pink, red, or dark in color. They often grow larger than the original wound and do not regress over time.
  • Location: Commonly occur on the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks but can appear anywhere on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors made up of blood vessels. They usually appear as red or purple marks and are often present at birth or develop shortly after.

 

Option C. Normal scar: A normal scar typically lies flat against the skin and does not extend beyond the boundary of the original wound. It is usually lighter in color compared to keloids.

 

Option D. Hamartoma: Hamartomas are benign, focal malformations that resemble neoplastic tissue but grow at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. They do not typically present as raised scars.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloids are characterized by an excessive overgrowth of scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often appearing thick and raised. They are more common in areas such as the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks. The clinical image and description provided align with the diagnosis of a keloid.

questions.text: A female presented in dermatology OPD with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

 

  • Since the patient is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy, syndromes associated with acne should be evaluated and ruled out to reach a diagnosis. One of the important syndrome is HAIR-AN syndrome.
  • Hence, the next best step would be to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Looking for dietary triggers: It could be considered, but this should already be taken care of before prescribing isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Option C. Checking for antibiotic resistance: This seems an appropriate step but can’t prioritize over ruling out HAIR-AN syndrome in this patient.

 

Option D. Drug triggers are unlikely to be the primary cause of acne patient who is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. Moreover, lesions in Drug-induced acne are monomorphic and comedones are absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, the next best step is to evaluate for hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS, necessitating a different treatment approach.

 

References: Williams Gynaecology 4th edition: page no 392-394

questions.text: Anticancer drug that can result in hand and foot syndrome is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Capecitabine is an oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and both of these drugs are known to cause hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia). This condition is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It occurs due to the leakage of the drug from capillaries in these areas, leading to skin toxicity. Hand-foot syndrome is a well-documented adverse effect of capecitabine, making it the correct answer in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is associated with a different side effect profile, most notably hemorrhagic cystitis, which can be prevented by the administration of mesna.

 

Option B. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis and can also result in flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: Paclitaxel is an anticancer drug that primarily causes peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine & 5FU can cause hand-foot syndrome, which is an important side effect to monitor in patients receiving this treatment.

questions.text: A patient with the respiratory difficulty and had a history of Chronic smoking. His pulmonary function testing showed decrease FEV1 %. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) COPD

 

Explanation: 

 

This case presents a classic presentation of COPD with several key diagnostic features:

 

  • History of smoking (major risk factor)
  • Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough (typical symptoms)
  • PFT findings showing: 
    • Decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic criteria for airflow obstruction/Obstructive disease)
    • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response(distinguishes from asthma very good improvement in FEV1) .
    • According to GOLD criteria, post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% confirms the presence of persistent airflow limitation and COPD diagnosis in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis shows a restrictive pattern on PFTs with FEV1/FVC ratio >70% and reduced total lung capacity, not an obstructive pattern as seen here.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): Incorrect because like pulmonary fibrosis, ILD demonstrates a restrictive pattern on PFTs, not obstruction. ILD would show decreased lung volumes with preserved FEV1/FVC ratio.

 

Option D. Asthma: Incorrect because although asthma can show decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio, it typically demonstrates significant bronchodilator reversibility (>12% and >200mL improvement in FEV1), which is not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for COPD: post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% with minimal bronchodilator response in a patient with risk factors and appropriate symptoms.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

 

Distichiasis refers to the additional row of eyelashes behind the grey line. It may happen as a result of inherited or acquired factors.

 

The cornea may become irritated by these lashes. The treatment involves separating the lids and applying cryotherapy to the hair follicles' bases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichiasis: Refers to the misdirection of eyelashes that grow inward towards the eye, causing irritation and potential damage to the cornea. The lid margin remains in its normal position.

 

Option C. Tylosis: Refers to the thickening of the tarsal plate, often associated with chronic inflammation and lid margin disease, but not related to an extra row of eyelashes.

 

Option D. Madarosis: Refers to the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, which can be due to various causes including trauma, systemic diseases, and dermatologic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

choices.text: Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism
Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically less than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically greater than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites

questions.text: A patient with decompensated liver cirrhosis presents with difficulty breathing due to significant ascites accumulation. Which of the following statements regarding the evaluation and cause of ascites is incorrect? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically less than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites

 

Explanation:

 

Ascites in cirrhosis is caused by portal hypertension, which increases hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity.

 

SAAG classification:

 

  • SAAG > 1.1 g/dL → Portal hypertension-related ascites (e.g., cirrhosis, heart failure, Budd-Chiari syndrome)
  • SAAG < 1.1 g/dL → Non-portal hypertension causes (e.g., malignancy, tuberculosis, pancreatitis)

 

Since cirrhosis-related ascites results from increased portal pressure, SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism: Correct; cirrhosis leads to RAAS activation, causing sodium and water retention

 

Option B. Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary: Correct; SAAG is calculated using these values

 

Option D. SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites:  Correct, as it reflects portal hypertension

 

Educational Objective:

 

The SAAG value helps differentiate portal hypertension-related ascites (>1.1 g/dL) from non-portal hypertension causes (<1.1 g/dL).

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute gout

 

The patient presents with acute pain and swelling in the left great toe, a common presentation of acute gout. Despite normal serum uric acid levels, the clinical presentation and the findings from the synovial fluid analysis point towards acute gout.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Acute Pain and Swelling of the Left Great Toe: This is characteristic of acute gout, especially involving the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint.
  2. No History of Trauma: This excludes traumatic causes of joint pain.
  3. Synovial Fluid Analysis Shows Raised Leukocytes: Indicates an inflammatory arthritis.
  4. Normal Serum Uric Acid Levels: In 30-40% of acute gout cases, serum uric acid levels can be normal due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint rather than in the bloodstream.

 

Acute Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints, leading to intense pain and swelling. The first MTP joint is the most commonly affected site. Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, particularly during an acute attack, due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint.

 

Diagnosis Confirmation: The diagnosis of gout is confirmed by joint aspiration and identification of negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudogout: This condition usually presents in elderly individuals and often involves the knee or wrist joints. The presence of chondrocalcinosis on X-ray and the involvement of joints like knee (MC), wrist or MCP joint (NOT first MTP joint) makes pseudogout less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Reactive Arthritis: This condition typically follows a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection and involves multiple joints. There is no mention of such a history in this patient.

 

Option D. Septic Arthritis: This condition is usually associated with more severe systemic symptoms like fever and a more aggressive clinical course. The patient's presentation does not match the typical features of septic arthritis.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, especially during an acute attack, and the involvement of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint is highly characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 54-year-old woman, underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation.
  •  Lymphedema is a common complication of breast cancer surgery, particularly when lymph nodes are removed or damaged during the procedure, leading to poor drainage of lymphatic fluid from the affected arm.
  • The swelling in lymphedema is usually painless, and the skin may feel tight or heavy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphangiosarcoma:  Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that can develop in the lymphatic vessels, often years after radiation therapy or surgery for breast cancer. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and skin changes in the affected area. However, it is a very uncommon complication compared to lymphedema.

 

Option C. Venous thrombosis: Venous thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in a vein, usually presenting with symptoms like swelling, pain, and warmth in the affected area. In this case, the swelling is painless and is more indicative of lymphatic fluid accumulation rather than a venous thrombosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissues, presenting with symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and warmth. The absence of warmth, redness, and tenderness in the patient's presentation makes cellulitis an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema is a common postoperative complication of breast cancer surgery due to the removal or damage of lymph nodes, leading to poor lymphatic drainage.
  •  It presents as painless swelling, heaviness, and skin thickening in the affected limb.

choices.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulphadoxine/Pyrimethamine 750/37.5 mg (2 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulphadoxine/Pyrimethamine 750/37.5 mg (2 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Rajasthan is diagnosed with mixed malaria infection – P. falciparum + P. vivax. Treatment regimen on Day 2 would be: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In cases of mixed malaria infection involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, the treatment approach differs from that of single-species infections.

 

For mixed infections, the primaquine dose is adjusted to 2.5 mg to target both liver and blood stages effectively, while artesunate is used to clear the parasitemia. Artesunate is typically given for three consecutive days, and the dosage of primaquine is reduced compared to when treating only P. falciparum, where the standard dose would be 7.5 mg. This regimen helps in managing mixed malaria effectively, ensuring both species are adequately targeted.

 

Note –

 

  • For patients from other parts of the country, ACT-SP (artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) plus primaquine is used.
  • For patients from northeast India, artemether-lumefantrine combination therapy is preferred.
  • Primaquine in mixed infections is given for 14 days, while in single infections, it is given only on the second day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed malaria infections involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, primaquine 2.5 mg is used on Day 2 along with artesunate to effectively treat both species.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoing treatment for tuberculosis reports experiencing a decrease in visual acuity and color blindness. Which of the following antitubercular drugs is most likely to cause visual problems? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that is known to cause optic neuritis, which is an inflammation of the optic nerve. This condition can lead to a decrease in visual acuity and color blindness, most notably red-green color blindness.

 

The mnemonic "E for Ethambutol, E for Eye problems" can be used to remember this association.

 

Ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is dose-dependent and can be reversible upon discontinuation of the drug, but if not identified early, it may result in permanent vision loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is associated with hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy, primarily due to its interference with vitamin B6 metabolism.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause orange discoloration of body fluids (urine, sweat, tears) and is a potent enzyme inducer, leading to multiple drug interactions.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is known to be hepatotoxic and can cause hyperuricemia, which may lead to gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis, leading to a decrease in visual acuity and red-green color blindness.
